item.title: Police bodycam use about to rise in Canada
item.description: After years of reluctance by police and government in Canada to embrace bodycams, Colin Freeze reports that things are beginning to change. His informative piece (behind a paywall at the Globe) notes a series of changes on the ground across Canada in the wake of George Floyd’s murder, captured on video last summer. Soon after that occurred, Trudeau announced $50 million in funding for RCMP bodycams. Ontario has recently announced $70 million in funding, with two of the province’s largest forces – Peel and Toronto – budgeting $10 and $34 million respectively for body-worn cameras.

item.title: About me
item.description: I teach and practice law in British Columbia. I work in the Faculty of Law at Thompson Rivers University and with the criminal defence firm Jensen Law in Kamloops, BC. I write journalism and scholarship on a range of topics, from law and technology to civil liberties and human rights. I co-edit of the Canadian Journal of Comparative and Contemporary Law, and hold a PhD in law from the University of British Columbia.
